bestBHT.bht: Amazed at the divine power accompanying the teaching of the Apostle, the deputy gives himself up to it. Being astonished at the doctrine of the Lord and the miraculous blindness that immediately followed, Sergius Paulus believes. His faith is not seen simply as a revenue-seeking belief, but rather, his joining the Christian brotherhood is evidence that the gospel was not confined to the poor and obscure. The word doctrine here denotes the wonderful effects connected with the teaching. While we do not know the exact fruit or duration of this conversion, Sergius Paulus' baptism is a natural inference.

Henry Alford: Hesitating as he had been before between the teaching of the sorcerer and that of the Apostle, he is amazed at the divine power accompanying the latter, and gives himself up to it.
It is not said that he was baptized: but the supposition is not thereby excluded: see ver. 48; ch. xvii. 12, 34; xviii. 8, first part.

The deputy hesitates between the teaching of the sorcerer and that of the Apostle, but is amazed at the divine power accompanying the latter. He gives himself up to it, being astonished at the doctrine of the Lord. The miraculous blindness that immediately follows confirms the power of the teaching. Sergius Paulus' belief goes beyond a mere revenue-seeking faith, as his baptism is a natural inference. This conversion of a man of high rank is an early example of the gospel's reach beyond the poor and obscure.
